label: CCPA-1
question: Is the CCPA section in a separate link (as opposed to in the same privacy policy?)

options.text: No, it's part of the same privacy policy
Yes, it's on a separate link or separate document
Not applicable, there is no CCPA section or CCPA reference in the contract

label: CCPA-2
question: Does the Policy state the firms' CCPA policy only applies to California residents? (for example, Tinder's states that "This California section supplements the Privacy Policy and applies solely to California consumers (excluding our personnel). The Table below describes how we process California consumers' personal information (excluding our personnel), based on definitions laid out in the California Consumer Privacy Act ("CCPA")."

options.text: Not applicable, there is no CCPA section or CCPA reference in the contract

label: CCPA-4
question: Directs CA Residents to that section when describing general (non-california exclusive) data practices?

options.text: Not applicable, there is no CCPA section or CCPA reference in the contract

label: CCPA-5
question: Personal Information Request: Offers CA residents an opportunity to request all information shared with third parties in the last year?

label: CCPA-6
question: Offers California residents a direct link via which to contact site and request information?

options.text: Direct link included in same section)

label: CCPA-7
question: Data requests are explicitly free of charge?

label: CCPA-8
question: Does the Policy list the categories of personal information sold in the past 12 months?

label: CCPA-9
question: Policy identifies at least two methods for submitting a personal information or erasure request, in accordance with CCPA? (These must include, at a minimum, a web page and a toll-free telephone number)

options.text: Two methods identified, but different from web page and toll-free number.

label: CCPA-3
question: Has California Privacy Rights Section that explains all rights afforded under the CCPA? (The right to request disclosure of business' data collection and sales practices , the categories of personal information collected, the source of the information,  use of the information and, if the information was disclosed or sold to third parties, the categories of personal information disclosed or sold to third parties and the categories of third parties to whom such information was disclosed or sold; The right to request a copy of the specific personal information collected about them during the 12 months before their request (together with right #1, a "personal information request"); The right to have such information deleted (with exceptions); he right to request that their personal information not be sold to third parties, if applicable; and The right not to be discriminated against because they exercised any of the new rights.]

label: CCPA-10
question: Firm offers the right of opt-out of selling personal information to third parties with a visible, direct link to "Do Not Sell My Personal Information."

options.text: Mentions the right but explains why it's not available/not applicable (e.g., firm does not sell information to third parties)

label: N-12
question: Is there layered notice or short notice? (i.e., are the key Policy terms giving users the gist of the contract summarized on top of the document or somewhere noticeable? Table of Contents does not qualify)

label: N-1
question: Does the company have a cookie policy? (note "Yes" if the company has a stated cookie policy (e.g., a section in the privacy policy explaining its cookie policy) or offers link to a document with it, or if there is an attached cookie policy in the coding tool)

label: N-2
question: Does the company explicitly state they use tracking elements other than cookies? (e.g. "local storage cookies", "browser fingerprints")?

label: N-3
question: Biometric Information Collected and Stored? (e.g., facial scans, fingerprints, facial patterns, voice or typing cadence)

label: N-4
question: Company commits that PII will be used internally only for business purposes ( e.g., effecting, administering, or enforcing a transaction, sending future correspondence to user, research, internal database compilation, servicing website)? [Article 4 of the GDPR, personal data is "any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person. In general, internal business purposes involve use of data for purposes that are in the service of the user)[Advertising is not considered internal business purposes; Article 6 of GDPR defines as legitimiate or "business purpose processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract;

options.text: Yes, but there are other terms in the policy that conflict with such commitment

label: N-5
question: Company commits to use PII (personally identifiable information) data only for stated context specific purposes. These are purposes that a user would expect in the context of the service provided.  E.g., what you post to a message board must be made public for a message board to work)?

options.text: Yes, but there are other terms in the policy that conflict with such commitment

label: N-6
question: Third party tracking: site allows third parties to place advertisements that may track user behavior?

label: N-7
question: Policy identifies third party recipients of shared or sold data? (General question)

options.text: Specific/named entity or named category of third party

label: N-8
question: Policy defines words such as "affiliates" or "third parties" if it uses them? (i.e.. the policy includes definitions of what it means by these categories; examples are not enough to classify as a definition)

label: N-9
question: Policy has a Change of Terms (COT) provision that explicitly or implicitly allows entity to change agreement?

label: N-10
question: Policy requires user to explicitly assent to material changes?

label: N-11
question: Policy states that material changes are retroactive?

options.text: Yes (applies to data made before the change)

label: N-13
question: Policy provides notice of data procedures if company is sold or otherwise ceases to exist (e.g., goes bankrupt)?

label: SH-1
question: Are affiliates and/or subsidiaries (specifically) bound by the same privacy policy, confidentiality agreements, or have a contract with firm outlining how data will be used and secured?

label: SH-2
question: Are contractors/service providers (under CCPA)/processors (under GDPR)  (e.g., payment process companies) bound by either the same privacy policy, confidentiality agreements, or have a contract with firm outlining how data will be used and secured?  (CCPA, GDPR compliance requirement)

label: SH-3
question: Are third parties bound by the same privacy policy?

options.text: Not applicable [this would be applicable if, for example, the company did not share information with third parties]

label: SH-4
question: Entity performs due diligence to ensure legitimacy of 3rd parties that have access to data?

label: SH-5
question: Entity has contract with 3rd parties (excluding processors/service providers) establishing how disclosed data can be used?

label: SH-6
question: Policy provides links to relevant 3rd parties' privacy policies? (sometimes the Policy includes links to third party privacy policies, usually when it states that any engagement with third parties will be governed by third party privacy policies

options.text: Not applicable (in cases where there are no relationships with third parties of any sort)

label: SH-7
question: What is consent mechanism for sharing/selling PII or sensitive information to entities that aren't service providers (except for the purpose of effecting, administering, or enforcing a transaction, sending future correspondence to user, research, internal database compilation, servicing website)?

options.text: Opt-out  [The default is for the user to share PII with third parties, but the Policy gives the user the opportunity to opt out]
Opt-in [User must consent before data can be shared with or collected/used by third party]
Not applicable (applicable if firm does not engage in this practice)

label: UC-2
question: Can users can adjust privacy settings?  [Double check on the website; directing user to control cookies via browser setting doesn't count]

label: UC-3
question: Are users allowed to access and correct/update personal data collected?

options.text: Can access and correct data, and 3rd parties notified of correction

label: UC-1
question: Can the user request that incorrect data be either rectified, updated, or erased?

options.text: Yes, within 30 days [in compliance with GDPR]

label: UC-4
question: Can user request that information be deleted or anonymized?

options.text: Yes (partial) [User can delete/anonymize account, but the company/organization may continue to keep some of the user's data]
Yes (full) [User can delete account and all of the user's information is removed from company/organization's servers/databases.]

label: UC-5
question: Ownership Rights of User Information Provided (look in terms of use)

options.text: User owns data, but licenses data to entity in a non-exclusive, royalty-free, form, with no right to compensation for company's use of the data
User owns the data but the license is not so broad as to permit the company to use, share, and commercialize data/proprietary media as it sees fit

label: UC-6
question: What happens to data if entity ceases to exist or is acquired?

options.text: Sold with company or otherwise distributed/disclosed [e.g., when the company liquidates and the assets are sold piecemal]
Sold but given continued protection under same Policy, or transferred to acquiring entity
User is given choice as to what happens with data

label: UC-7
question: If company is sold or goes bankrupt, user is given choice as to what happens to their data?

label: UC-8
question: If user quits site, what happens to personal data?

options.text: Retained and treated as if user is still using service

label: SE-1
question: Policy guarantees data accuracy (must say the word "data accuracy" for this to be relevant)?

label: SE-2
question: Policy specifies reasonable procedures in place to ensure accuracy? (Even a little procedure qualifies)

label: SE-3
question: Policy reserves right to disclose protected information to comply with law/prevent crime?

label: SE-4
question: Policy reserves right to disclose protected information to protect its own rights?

label: SE-5
question: Users will be given notice of government requests for information about the user.

label: SE-6
question: User will be notified of data breach?

label: SE-7
question: Policy describes substantive privacy and security protections incorporated into entity's managerial/structural procedures (e.g., limiting the number of employees who have access to data, allowing data access only for job-related functions, assigning employees to oversee privacy issues, employing Chief Privacy Officer, requiring periodic audits)? (General question)

label: SE-8
question: Policy specifically identifies means of technological security (e.g., encryption)?

label: DP-1
question: Does company have a procedure for safely disposing unused/no longer needed data?

label: E-1
question: Policy provides means by which user can contact site with privacy concerns and/or complaints? [select all that apply]

options.text: yes, and mentions it in accordance with CCPA [or listed under a CCPA section in Policy]
yes, and mentions it in accordance with GDPR [or listed under a GDPR section in Policy]

label: E-2
question: Policy has forum selection clause? If so, which forum?

label: E-3
question: Policy has choice of law clause?  If so, which law?

label: E-4
question: Policy has arbitration clause?

label: E-5
question: Policy has class action waiver?

label: E-6
question: Policy disclaims liability for failure of security measures?

label: E-7
question: Policy provides link to FTC's Consumer Complaint Form and/or the FTC telephone number? [this just asks if the Policy mentions the FTC's consumer complaint form at all or provides links to it]

label: E-8
question: What privacy seal/certification/industry oversight organization does Policy claim [other than mandatory international law (Swiss Privacy Law, etc)? [Privacy Seals are independent, third-party enforcement programs to monitor company practices and enforce privacy policies. They are designed to provide protection to consumers by allowing Web companies to standardize privacy policies. Privacy seal programs include, among others, TRUSTe, BBBOnline, and CPA Webtrust. These are different from regulatory compliance seals, such as those that the company complies with COPPA, the Children Online Privacy Protection Act).

label: PBD-1
question: Policy requires periodic compliance review of structural and technological data security measures?

label: PBD-2
question: Policy contains self-reporting measures in case of privacy violation (to a privacy seal organization, 3rd party consultant)?

label: K-1
question: Is the Privacy Policy incorporated by reference in the Terms of use?

label: GDPR-1
question: Policy states that it is GDPR compliant or includes section on GDPR compliance

label: GDPR-2
question: Does Policy state it complies with EU-US Privacy Shield?

label: GDPR-3
question: Does Policy state that GDPR terms apply only and exclusively to EU residents?

label: GDPR-4
question: Can users object to processing or automated decision making that could impact them? (This is only applicable if company does profiling or any other automated decision making, such as algorithmic decision making, or any automated decisions that don't involve a human)

label: GDPR-5
question: If firm engages in automated decision making, does it provide meaningful information about the logic involved, or significance/effect of such decisions?

label: COVID-1
question: Does the Policy include any terms related to contact tracing, health tracking, or other terms in relationship to COVID?
